articles.headline: In Europe, a Move to Slash Phone Roaming Charges
articles.snippet: The European Commission will propose for the first time a limit on the fees that consumers pay to surf the Internet while traveling in the European Union.
articles.abstract: The European Commission will propose for the first time a limit on the fees that consumers pay to surf the Internet while traveling in the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: For many tourists, it’s an experience they will long remember. After taking in the Eiffel Tower in Paris, the Coliseum in Rome or Buckingham Palace in London, they arrive home to something unexpected: a staggering cellphone roaming bill.

articles.headline: Casey Anthony Not Guilty in Slaying of Daughter
articles.snippet: An Orlando jury found Ms. Anthony guilty of lesser charges in a case that transfixed America for three years.
articles.abstract: An Orlando jury found Ms. Anthony guilty of lesser charges in a case that transfixed America for three years.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Casey Anthony, the young mother whose seeming heartlessness at the disappearance of her daughter transfixed America for three years, was found not guilty on Tuesday of killing the girl, Caylee Marie.

articles.headline: U.S. to Prosecute a Somali Suspect in Civilian Court
articles.snippet: A Somali man accused of ties to two Islamist militant groups was captured and interrogated for months aboard a Navy ship before being sent to New York for a civilian trial.
articles.abstract: A Somali man accused of ties to two Islamist militant groups was captured and interrogated for months aboard a Navy ship before being sent to New York for a civilian trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration announced Tuesday that it would prosecute in civilian court a Somali accused of ties to two Islamist militant groups. The decision to fly the man to New York for trial, after interrogating him for months aboard a United States naval vessel, is likely to reignite debate about the detention and prosecution of terrorism suspects.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: A Safer Nuclear Crypt
articles.snippet: With more scrutiny on spent fuel pools in the United States, some are pointing to dry casks as a storage option.
articles.abstract: With more scrutiny on spent fuel pools in the United States, some are pointing to dry casks as a storage option.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARSEILLES, Ill. — Watching intently as a huge white steel container surfaced from a 42-foot-deep canal, workers set upon it with long-handled tools, like sailors wrestling a flailing whale to the deck of a ship.

articles.headline: Zuckerberg Finds Fans on Google+
articles.snippet: Google’s new social networking site hasn’t been active for long, but the founder of Facebook, a rival, has already signed up — and has gained friends.
articles.abstract: Google’s new social networking site hasn’t been active for long, but the founder of Facebook, a rival, has already signed up — and has gained friends.
articles.lead_paragraph: Any guesses as to who is the most popular person on Google+, the company’s new social networking service? Ashton Kutcher, perhaps? Or Lady Gaga?

articles.headline: Big Business Leaves Deficit to Politicians
articles.snippet: Corporate America has been little help as politicians struggle with the nation’s deficit problem; one group, the Business Roundtable, demonstrates why.
articles.abstract: Corporate America has been little help as politicians struggle with the nation’s deficit problem; one group, the Business Roundtable, demonstrates why.

articles.headline: Murdoch Facing Parliament’s Ire in Hacking Case
articles.snippet: From all sides of the House of Commons the disgust came thick and fast, as the legislators recited the most recent allegations against The News of the World.
articles.abstract: From all sides of the House of Commons the disgust came thick and fast, as the legislators recited the most recent allegations against The News of the World.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s Parliament on Wednesday collectively turned on Rupert Murdoch, the head of the News Corporation, and the tabloid culture he represents, using a debate about a widening phone hacking scandal to denounce reporting tactics by newspapers once seen as too politically influential to challenge.

articles.headline: As Plastic Reigns, the Treasury Slows Its Printing Presses
articles.snippet: Production of most paper cash fell markedly last year, as credit cards remained entrenched and paper bills were lasting much longer.
articles.abstract: Production of most paper cash fell markedly last year, as credit cards remained entrenched and paper bills were lasting much longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The number of dollar bills rolling off the great government presses here and in Fort Worth fell to a modern low in the last fiscal year. Production of $5 bills also dropped to the lowest level in 30 years. And for the first time in that period, the Treasury Department did not print any $10 bills.
